key_behaviors: Uses ChatGPT multiple times per day for personal tasks
Leverages ChatGPT to draft, summarize, and shorten personal emails
Employs ChatGPT for brainstorming and refining ideas in UX‑related passion projects
Saves conversation history in ChatGPT’s left‑hand panel and organizes by project folders
Relies on Google, news sites, and social media for real‑time information instead of ChatGPT
Provides feedback to ChatGPT when its suggestions diverge from intended direction
pain_points: Long email drafts require manual condensation; wants quicker summarisation
When AI suggestions stray from the intended idea, extra mental effort is needed to evaluate and correct them
Lack of seamless integration with Gmail and Apple Calendar forces copy‑paste workflow
ChatGPT does not provide real‑time data (weather, prices, news)
Uncertainty about how AI could connect to other productivity apps
trust_factors: Trust increases when AI improves grammar, conciseness, and generates useful ideas
Trust decreases when AI leads the user away from their original concept
Confidence in AI’s ability to remember past conversations via saved chat history
desires: AI that builds directly on the user’s prompt without deviating from the original intent
Native integration or plug‑in with Gmail for drafting and editing emails within the email client
Connection to Apple Calendar (and other tools) for reminders and scheduling
More robust memory across sessions beyond the current folder view
Ability to access real‑time information without leaving the chat

verbatim_quotes.quote: I primarily use ChatGPT sometimes when I'm writing personal emails, ... I love to put it in ChatGPT to see if it can help me spruce it up and make it a bit better, ensuring that I'm providing the best information on my projects or emails, including grammar and content.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Purpose: email writing and quality improvement

verbatim_quotes.quote: when I'm using ChatGPT and I, like, ask it to, like, for example, summarize this long email or just make it a bit shorter so it's a lot, like, concise and easy to scan and not too much wording

For my passion projects, same kinda idea. ... when I'm, like, kinda stuck sometimes, I'm able to, like, put this idea in a chat GPT, and it's like, hey. What do you think about this? Or, how can I, like, make this a bit better kinda thing?
verbatim_quotes.topic: Purpose: brainstorming and idea refinement for passion projects

verbatim_quotes.quote: I'm working on a project where I'm trying to build a web application. ChatGPT helps me improve upon the ideas I have, which allows me to move on to the next step within the project or even sparks new ideas.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Use case: UX design and project progression

verbatim_quotes.quote: once I, like, put in, like, the first thing that I wanted like, the main focus and the main, like, offering of the app, ChatGPT, like, spit out some more ideas of things that I could include in the future
I haven't really encountered a time where I wanted to use AI for something and couldn't
No, I haven't used it to do any real-time information tasks. I typically use Google or watch the news a lot
verbatim_quotes.topic: Preference for other sources for live data

verbatim_quotes.quote: I think ChatGPT kind of already does that if you have an account. When you type in a prompt and stuff, I see that on the left-hand panel, it saves the conversation.
the most important thing for the AI to do is to build upon your prompting, your idea, and not really make you stray away from anything
verbatim_quotes.topic: Desired AI behavior: stay aligned with user intent

verbatim_quotes.quote: When it takes me in a direction I didn't intend, I sit and think about what the AI returned and why it said that. However, sometimes I might not even go with that idea.
Maybe connecting it with Gmail or your Apple Calendar, stuff like that, to remind you of things.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Desired integration with email and calendar

verbatim_quotes.quote: I guess for Gmail, it would definitely help when I'm writing an email, so I don't always have to put my draft email, write it up in Gmail or in my Apple Notes, copy it, and then paste it into ChatGPT. I think it would be easier if it was a plug-in.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Desired plug‑in for seamless email drafting

verbatim_quotes.quote: I actually haven't been interviewed by AI yet. I'm sure that's probably going to come in the future.
I guess that it feels a bit it doesn't feel too, like, strange because it's not it's just recording my voice and returning a prompt and, like, a, not a prompt. We're returning information.
it feels more seamless because it's not like I mentioned before, it's not like a fake person or an AI-generated person on the other side of the computer.

unique_insights: The participant reports no major functional failures despite heavy daily use, which is uncommon among users who typically encounter limitations. Their trust is moderate and hinges on the AI staying tightly aligned with their own ideas; they view AI divergence as a cognitive cost rather than a creative benefit. Additionally, the participant finds a text‑only AI interview experience surprisingly seamless because there is no visual avatar, highlighting that perceived 'human‑likeness' may not be necessary for comfort.
